comment_text: Can't wait for artemis 3 to bring back those days

Brother Tim, I swear, you HAVE to make more music! Been listening to the ones available for a long time, and they just don't get old, but some new sounds from you would be awesome! Tell us you haven't given up on music production, Please!
Videos of people acting stupid in public.
Tim Dodd has not only captured the proudest moment in American History but also the happiest day in 13.8 Billion Years.

This is the groovin'-est chillin' little jam ever, with just the right amount funky rubbed on it.
It delivers a unique heartfelt nostalgic contrast with the video edit and seamlessly ties all the snippets of events that day with a groovin' little repetitive rhythm.

You know, I'm Pavlov trained with this song. Let me explain. You always use this on your outros, and your videos are so good, first of all I love rockets, and also seeing the progress (primarily) SpaceX is making towards a new space age that your videos make me feel optimistic about life, a life with a multiplanetary species, where space travel is common, and I probably feel similar than people felt with the first space race and the Moon landings. And your videos just make me feel like there's a bright future ahead. So then there's this song. As I said, you always play this song in the end of your videos, and by that time I'm always happy for the aforementioned reasons. And I recently realized I ended up associating this song with happiness. That's a beautiful thing, because now that I'm listening to it I feel so happy for no apparent reason, and now I realize I'm so glad this channel exists, the positivity you bring is incredible. Thank you!

Dear Tim, many thanks for this video! (and great music, of course) I watch the clip over and over and I always find some great detail. I have no idea where you got the material in such luxurious quality. It's hard to believe that it's been more than 50 years since the Apollo 11 flight. My parents weren't even 18 at the time, and the beautiful laughing girls at 0:49 and 0:59 are now 70-year-old ladies. I would love to experience that time, it must have been fantastic. Here, too, behind the Iron Curtain, people watched Apollo with bated breath and kept their fingers crossed. Greetings from Prague in the Czech Republic, it's such a tiny spot in the middle of Europe 😁
